Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Differential Geometry and Statistics of Deformation Tensors
Award.AbstractNarration:
Structural geology data and models rely on a variety of geometric concepts, such as directions in space, ellipsoids, and deformation tensors. In mathematics, these objects are often represented as elements of Lie groups and their associated symmetric spaces. This vast mathematical theory has been applied to geology in only a few instances. This project represents collaboration between two structural geologists and a mathematician; the goal is to develop three new applications of Lie groups to problems within structural geology. The first uses Lie group-based differential equations methods to compute non-steady deformations. This method is being applied to an existing dataset from a shear zone in New Caledonia. The second applies established statistics of ellipsoids to finite strain ellipsoid data from South Mountain, Maryland, which is a classic field location within the field of structural geology. The third develops a statistical theory of deformation tensors, and uses them to compute best-fit deformations and to quantify the uncertainty in data and models.

This project enriches the fundamental tool set that geologists use to describe data and make inferences from data. It opens the door to further cross-fertilization among geology, mathematics, and other fields using related techniques, such as medical imaging. The products of the project will be disseminated in scholarly publications, short courses, and free software distributed to the geology community. The project will facilitate collaboration and research between faculty from a four-year college and a research-intensive university. The study will contribute to undergraduate education at both institutions, and will provide funding for undergraduate research projects.

This project is supported by funds from the NSF EAR Tectonics Program and the Collaborations in Mathematical Geosciences Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Structural geology is the study of rock deformation: how rock fractures, folds, and flows under the extreme stresses found within the Earth. As a basic science, structural geology informs various applications, including earthquake hazard assessment and natural resources exploration. This project developed new techniques for the analysis of rock deformation, using a branch of mathematics, Lie theory, that has been under-utilized in structural geology.


Intellectual Merit

The practice of structural geology has typically not utilized statistical analyses except in limited contexts. Reasons include the wide range of spatial scales, non-uniform spacing of measurements due to limited outcrops, lack of standardization of field protocols, small sample sizes, and unusual data types not treatable by elementary methods.

This grant funded a bottom-up approach to dealing with structural geology data in a statistically robust way. We began by demonstrating how to integrate a wide variety of data into the construction of best-fit deformation models. Our focus then shifted to understanding the uncertainty in those models. We used three main kinds of statistics: directional, orientational, and ellipsoidal. Our techniques addressed several basic tasks in data analysis: visualization, inference about populations, regression, and so on. In some cases we assembled these techniques from other disciplines (medical imaging, robotics, materials science, etc.) and tested their applicability to structural geology. In other cases we developed novel methods, including fast, robust simulation of deforming rock particles, density contouring of orientational data, and anisotropic confidence regions for mean orientations. An unexpected outcome was a new method of crystallographic vorticity analysis, which determines the direction of shearing-induced rotation in a flow.

To test our methods we collected three data sets: Bogota shear zone (New Caledonia), South Mountain (Maryland, USA), and Pilbara craton (Australia). Our statistical and computational approach, built on the fundamental mathematics of Lie theory, allowed us to characterize uncertainty in the rock fabrics.


Broader Impacts

This funding supported two young PIs at the start of their careers. The funding was especially critical for the research scientist, who was transitioning from a pure math background towards more applied science projects. We also ran a seminar on application of the statistical methods to structural geology datasets, which involved six graduate students and two post-doctoral fellows. Four of the graduate students' projects directly involve the statistical techniques as a significant component of their theses. The PIs also ran a short course at the 2015 Geological Society of America national meeting that included 20 participants. More short courses are planned. The short course notes, including a significant library of programming tools, is available online. Dissemination includes publication of results in scientific journals and presentations at conferences.
